messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Notes on Boolean Read-k and Multilinear Circuits

Paper Abstract: Abstract A monotone Boolean (‚à®,‚àß)(\lor,\land) circuit computing a monotone Boolean function fùëìf is a read-kùëòk circuit if the polynomial produced (purely syntactically) by the arithmetic (+,√ó)(+,\times) version of the circuit has the property that for every prime implicant of fùëìf, the polynomial contains at least one monomial with the same set of variables, each appearing with degree ‚©Ωkabsentùëò\leqslant k. Every monotone circuit is a read-kùëòk circuit for some kùëòk. We show that already read-1 (‚à®,‚àß)(\lor,\land) circuits are not weaker than monotone arithmetic constant-free (+,√ó)(+,\times) circuits computing multilinear polynomials, are not weaker than non-monotone multilinear (‚à®,‚àß,¬¨)(\lor,\land,\neg) circuits computing monotone Boolean functions, and have the same power as tropical (min,+)(\min,+) circuits solving 0/1010/1 minimization problems. Finally, we show that read-2 (‚à®,‚àß)(\lor,\land) circuits can be exponentially smaller than read-1 (‚à®,‚àß)(\lor,\land) circuits.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The monotone circuit complexity of Boolean functions",
        "Colorings and orientations of graphs",
        "The complexity of partial derivatives",
        "A Boolean function requiring 3n network size",
        "Algebraic Complexity Theory",
        "Partial derivatives in arithmetic complexity and beyond",
        "Boolean Functions: Theory, Algorithms, and Applications, volume 142 of Encyclopedia of Mathematics and Its Applications",
        "On one method of obtaining lower bounds on the monotone complexity of polynomials",
        "A method for deriving lower bounds for the complexity of monotone arithmetic circuits computing real polynomials",
        "Complexity of tropical Schur polynomials",
        "Tropical combinatorial Nullstellensatz and sparse polynomials",
        "On the parallel evaluation of multivariate polynomials",
        "An explicit lower bound of 5n - o(n) for boolean circuits",
        "Some exact complexity results for straight-line computations over semirings",
        "Boolean Function Complexity: Advances and Frontiers",
        "Lower bounds for monotone counting circuits",
        "Tropical complexity, Sidon sets and dynamic programming",
        "Approximation limitations of pure dynamic programming",
        "The effect of algebraic structure on the computation complexity of matrix multiplications",
        "Norm-graphs and bipartite Tur√°n numbers",
        "On the incompressibility of monotone DNFs",
        "Circuits composed of functional elements without zero paths in the basis {&,‚à®,‚àí}\\{\\&,\\lor,-\\}",
        "Explicit lower bound of 4.5n-o(n) for boolean circuits",
        "A note on lower bounds for monotone multilinear Boolean circuits",
        "Computing the maximum using (min,+) formulas",
        "Shortest path length with bounded-alternation (min,+) formulas",
        "Minimal relay-diode bipoles for monotonic symmetric functions",
        "Lower bounds on arithmetic circuits via partial derivatives",
        "Comparing the sizes of nondeterministic branching read-k-times programs",
        "Monotone multilinear boolean circuits for bipartite perfect matching require exponential size",
        "Separation of multilinear circuit and formula size",
        "Multi-linear formulas for Permanent and Determinant are of super-polynomial size",
        "Multilinear formulas, maximal-partition discrepancy and mixed-sources extractors",
        "Lower bounds for the monotone complexity of some boolean functions",
        "Lower bounds on monotone complexity of the logical permanent",
        "On the method of approximations",
        "Zwei lineare untere Schranken f√ºr die Komplexit√§t Boolescher Funktionen",
        "A lower bound on the number of additions in monotone computations",
        "Multilinearity can be exponentially restrictive (preliminary version)",
        "Non-cancellative boolean circuits: a generalization of monotone boolean circuits",
        "On the depth complexity of formulas",
        "Arithmetic circuits: A survey of recent results and open questions",
        "Vermeidung von Divisionen",
        "On separating the read-k-times branching program hierarchy",
        "A 4‚Äãn4ùëõ4n-lower bound on the mononotonenetwork complexity of a one-output boolean function",
        "A direct version of Shamir and Snir‚Äôs lower bounds on monotone circuit depth",
        "Negation can be exponentially powerful",
        "The complexity of Boolean functions",
        "Separating monotone VP and VNP"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Notes on Boolean Read-k and Multilinear Circuits, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
